REASONING: 

Ensuring the security of Pink and strengthening Gray's relationships with strategic partners form the crux of the priorities. Sharing intelligence on threats with Pink (B) is a fairly low-risk move that can help Pink protect itself and offer valuable insights to Gray about Brown's tactics. A high-level visit of Pink (A) to strengthen relationships aligns with Gray's objective of supporting Pink's security. Military posturing or exercise (H) sends a message of strength to Brown without engaging in direct combat. The establishment of defense and security cooperation agreements (C) bolsters the strategic alliance between Gray and Pink, while also serving as a deterrent to Brown. Criticizing Brown's actions (G) publicly can help drum up international support and possibly pressure Brown into deescalating the situation. 

Engaging in international arbitration (E) and starting formal peace negotiations (F) have been ranked in the middle due to the uncertain outcome of these processes and potential for time consumption. 

Lastly, options relating to offensive actions, such as executing a targeted attack (P), full-on invasion (Q), or any form of nuclear strike (R, S) are least favored due to the high risk and potential for escalation. Cutting diplomatic relationships with Brown (L) is also unfavorable as it limits options for diplomatic resolution.

Less reasonable options include a cybersecurity attack (O) and executing a targeted attack (P) which can provoke retaliation and spiral into a larger conflict. Full-on invasion (Q), tactical nuclear strike (R) and executing a full nuclear attack (S) are least reasonable as all these steps could lead to war and momentous loss of lives and international standing.
